Project Description 

The  Project  will  produce  the  following  outputs:  (i)  rehabilitation  and 
improvement  of  about  123  kilometers  (km)  of  core  network  roads;  (ii) 
labor-intensive  routine  road  maintenance  on  45  km;  (iii)  sound  and 
sustainable  road  maintenance  policies;  (iv)  an  efficient  bidding  and 
contracting  system  for  engaging  communities  in  road  maintenance 
through  local  small  contractors;  (v)  improved  project  management, 
supervision,  and  monitoring;  and  (vi)  identification  of  modalities  to 
ensure sustained rehabilitation and maintenance of rural feeder roads. 

Timor-Leste  is  one  of  the  least-developed  countries  in  the  world.  Per 
capita  gross  domestic  product  was  estimated  at  $405  in  2004. 
Officially,  more  than  40%  of  the  population  is  reported  to  live  under 
$0.55  per  day,  the  national  poverty  line.  However,  according  to  the 
estimates  of  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  technical  assistance  for 
Transport Sector Improvement, poverty prevalence is likely as high as 
88%, and approximately 46% of the population live in absolute poverty. 
During  the  1999  conflict,  most  communication  and  power  facilities 
were destroyed. In spite of some restoration efforts, postal services are 
still  closed  except  in  Baucau  and  Dili.  The  electrification  ratio  for  all 
households  is  only  20%;  95%  of  rural  households  are  without 
electricity. About 48% of the population does not have access to safe 
water  supply,  and  69%  does  not  have  access  to  adequate  sanitation 
facilities. Access to health facilities remains problematic. The time and 
money  costs  to  reach  a  community  health  center  or  a  hospital  are 
substantial.  Life  expectancy  is  low—less  than  60  years.  Currently, 
about a third of children are not enrolled in primary school; 20% of the 
enrolled  do  not  attend  classes.  More  than  half  the  population  is 
illiterate. Markets are either nonexistent or access is prevented due to 
mountainous topography, poor transport system, and lack of transport 
services. 

As  a  new  nation,  Timor-Leste  faces  many  challenges.  The  most 
pressing  issues  include  (i)  sustained  economic  growth,  (ii)  poverty 
reduction,  (iii)  employment,  (iv)  a  legal  and  institutional  framework  to 
manage  and  administer  the  new  nation  state  and  transform  the 
agrarian subsistence production to a market-oriented economy, and (v) 
weak human and institutional capacity. 

 ii 

 

In  the  short  term,  economic  growth  and  employment  have  to  come 
from  infrastructure  investments.  The  Government  recognizes  that 
infrastructure  is  of  overarching  importance  to  all  sectors  of  the 
economy and society; and that improving infrastructure, particularly the 
transport  system,  is  critical  in  fostering  private  sector  development, 
improving  agricultural  productivity, 
reducing  poverty,  promoting 
investment  and  human  development,  and  strengthening  government 
capacity  to  deliver  services.  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program 
update  for  2005  identifies  infrastructure  development  and  institutional 
capacity  building  as  the  major  areas  for  ADB  assistance.  ADB  has 
recently  approved  a  technical  assistance  to  address  cross-sectoral 
infrastructure issues and technical capacity building in the road sector. 
The Project, therefore, will focus on physical road infrastructure and its 
implementation.  As  a  post-conflict  country,  Timor-Leste  is  eligible  for 
grant financing from the Asian Development Fund. 

Impact and Outcome  The Project is expected to contribute to economic growth and poverty 
reduction.  It  will  (i)  improve  accessibility  for  project  area  residents  to 
food, and economic and social services; (ii) promote private sector-led 
industrial  and  agricultural  development;  (iii)  foster  market  formation 
and  facilitate  domestic  and  international  trade;  and  (iv)  generate 
income and employment opportunities. The outcome will be improved 
road infrastructure for economic and social development.

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Timor-Leste is a small and mountainous island country, with a population of 925,000 and 
a  land  area  of  14,609  square  kilometers.  It  is  located  at  the  eastern  end  of  the  Sunda 
archipelago  and  has  a  dramatic  topography  dominated  by  the  Ramelau  Mountains  stretching 
across  the  middle  of  the  island  from  the  east  to  the  west.  The  coastal  zones  in  the  north  and 
south are narrow, and are largely on steep hillsides. 

3. 
Roads provide the dominant mode of transport, carrying about 70% of freight and 90% 
of  passenger  traffic.  The  total  length  of  the  extensive  road  network  is  estimated  at  6,040 
kilometers (km), comprising 1,430 km of national roads linking district centers, 870 km of district 
roads  providing  links  to  large  administrative  centers,  and  720  km  in  Dili  and  several  smaller 
regional towns. The remaining 3,020 km are rural access or feeder roads. 

The extensive and dense road network was constructed with relatively low standards of 
4. 
design and materials. A pragmatic approach adapting to the often severe terrain conditions was 
used,  resulting  in  a  very  low  horizontal  and  vertical  geometrical  standard  in  mountainous 
regions.  The  road  widths  appear  to  have  been  compromised  according  to  the  actual  terrain 
conditions,  resulting  in  many  very  narrow  roads.  While  100%  of  national  roads  and  71%  of 
district  roads  were  bitumen  paved,  shoulders  are  often  constructed  out  of  impervious  earthen 
material.  This,  combined  with  the  difficult  geological  conditions,  torrential  rains,  and  lack  of 
maintenance,  has  caused  rapid  deterioration  of  the  road  system.  Only  24%  of  national  roads 
and 11% of district roads are currently in good condition. 

5. 
Traffic volume is small and concentrated around Dili. Traffic counts in 2000 showed that 
one third of the road network outside the urban center carried more than 200 vehicles per day 
(with  15%  carrying  more  than  500  vehicles  per  day,  less  than  2%  carrying  more  than  1,000 
vehicles per day). One third of the network carried less than 50 vehicles per day. Traffic counts 
in 2005 estimate the average daily traffic for motorized vehicles at about 160 on national roads, 
90  on  district  roads,  30  on  rural  roads,  and  170  on  urban  roads.  The  heaviest  traffic  flows  in 
excess of 400 vehicles per day are on the northern coastal road. 

6. 
Walking  is  the  most  common  mode  of  transportation,  followed  by  small  trucks,  and 
microbuses.  Transport  services  are  mainly  provided  by  small-scale  private  companies  owning 
one or two vehicles, and a small number of vehicle owner-operators. The Government has set 
minimum taxi fare rates, but has not set rates for passenger and freight buses and trucks.  

7. 
Drivers’  associations  are  apparently  developing  and  setting  rates.  Passenger  fares 
range from $0.50 to $3.00, depending on distance, averaging approximately $1.00 per one-way 
trip. This is high and not affordable for many rural people, particularly the poor. These rates do 
not  provide  a  decent  livelihood  for  vehicle  operators/owners:  almost  half  are  estimated  to  be 
living  below  the  national  poverty  line.  Operating  costs  are  high;  repair  costs  average  about 
$1,500 per year. Nearly 50% of the total repair costs are caused by the poor road conditions.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

As a post-conflict country emerging from 3 years of United Nations (UN) administration, 
10. 
Timor-Leste faces many challenges and opportunities. The most pressing include (i) sustained 
economic growth, (ii) poverty reduction, (iii) employment, (iv) a legal and institutional framework 
to  manage  and  administer  the  new  nation  state  and  transform  the  agrarian  subsistence 
production to a market-oriented economy, and (v) weak human and institutional capacity. 

1. 

Problems 

Economic  Growth.  The  large  influx  of  UN  forces,  bilateral  and  multilateral  donors, 
11. 
foreign experts, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and financial aid boosted consumption 
and  investment,  and  generated  income  and  job  opportunities.  Real  gross  domestic  product 
(GDP) growth was estimated at 18% in 2000 and 15% in 2001. But with the winding down of the 
international  assistance,  economic  growth  fell  significantly  in  2002  to  an  estimated  3%,  and 
became negative in 2003 (minus 3%). Growth in 2004 was moderate at about 1%. 

12. 
Poverty.  Timor-Leste  is  one  of  the  least-developed  countries  in  the  world,  in  terms  of 
per  capita  GDP,  estimated  at  $405  in  2004.  Officially,  more  than  40%  of  the  population  is 
reported  to  live  below  the  national  poverty  line  of  $0.55  per  day.  However,  according  to 
estimates  of  ADB  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Transport  Sector  Improvement,1  poverty 
prevalence is likely to be as high as 88%, and approximately 46% live in absolute poverty. As 
three  quarters  of  the  population  reside  in  rural  areas,  surviving  on  subsistence  and  seasonal 
agriculture,  poverty  is  predominantly  a  rural  phenomenon.  During  the  1999  conflict,  most 
communication and power facilities were destroyed. In spite of some restoration efforts, postal 
services are still closed except in Baucau and Dili. The electrification ratio for all households is 
only 20%; 95% of rural households are without electricity. About 48% of the population do not 
have  access  to  safe  water  supplies,  and  69%  do  not  have  access  to  adequate  sanitation 
facilities.  Access  to  health  facilities  remains  a  problem.  The  time  and  money  costs  to  reach  a 
community  health  center  or  a  hospital  are  substantial  (70  minutes  by  walking  and  2  hours  by 
minibus, $1 on average for one-way bus fare). Life expectancy is low, less than 60 years. While 
access  to  schooling  improved  considerably  prior  to  1999,  the  quality  of  teaching  and  learning 
was  low.  Currently,  about  a  third  of  children  are  not  enrolled  in  primary  school;  20%  of  the 
enrolled do not attend classes. More than half of the population is illiterate. Markets are either 
nonexistent or access is prevented or severely hampered due to mountainous topography, poor 
transport system, and lack of transport services.  

13. 
Employment. The total fertility rate is very high, estimated to be 8.3. Every year, about 
16,000 new workers enter the labor force. The rapid increase in population and labor force has

14. 
Legal and Institutional Framework. Timor-Leste emerged from the conflict with large-
scale devastation. With the 1999 referendum, linkages to the Indonesian legal and institutional 
framework  were  severed.  With  international  assistance,  a  government  structure  has  taken 
shape.  Some  laws  and  regulations  have  been  promulgated.  However,  the  process  of 
introducing necessary laws and regulations is slow. The Government’s organizational structure 
is  still  evolving  and  subject  to  constant  changes.  These  create  risks  and  uncertainties  for  the 
private  sector  as  well  as  donor  agencies.  The  organizational  change  of  the  Ministry  of 
Transport,  Communications,  and  Public  Works,  initially  formed  in  2002,  is  a  good  illustration. 
The Government recently split the ministry into the Ministry of Transport and Communications 
and Ministry of Public Works (MPW).  

15.  Weak Human and Institutional Capacity. The human resource base is low as a result 
of  the  conflict  and  tragedies.  Administrative,  managerial,  entrepreneurial,  technical,  and 
vocational skills are in short supply in all sectors of the economy. Middle to senior managerial 
positions are difficult to fill with qualified people. The vast majority of current civil servants are 
neither  experienced  nor  trained  for  the  roles  they  are  undertaking.  The  Government  depends 
heavily on foreign experts for daily administrative operations, policy formulation, and preparation 
and implementation of development projects. The problem is also acute in the road sector. The 
Directorate  of  Roads,  Bridges,  and  Flood  Control,  which  is  responsible  for  provision  and 
management  of  road  infrastructure,  has  only  12  staff,  of  a  total  of  91,  with  technical 
qualifications. They have limited skills in the formulation of technical standards, road planning, 
prioritization,  project  preparation  and  implementation,  and  asset  management,  and  have  to 
focus on managing emergency repair work. 

16. 
Social,  Gender,  and  Health-Related  Issues.  Difficult  terrain,  geology,  and  weather 
conditions  contribute  to  the  isolation  of  local  communities  and  severely  limit  access  to  water 
supplies,  energy,  food,  basic  social  services  (health  and  education),  and  local  markets.  The 
poor  conditions  of  rural  feeder  roads  especially  affect  rural  women,  who  are  responsible  for 
carrying  clean  water,  collecting  fodder  and  fuelwood,  and  marketing  agriculture  products.  To 
ensure  tangible  benefits  to  poor  and  isolated  communities,  the  rehabilitation  of  national  roads 
should  be  accompanied  by  an  increasing  focus  on  the  rehabilitation  of  secondary  and  rural 
feeder roads to ensure connectivity to markets, towns, and health and educational facilities. This 
complementary  approach  is  likely  to  increase  the  anticipated  poverty  reduction  impact  of  road 
improvement. Strengthening the capacity of local communities to prioritize and sequence their 
needs in terms of feeder road rehabilitation and maintenance contributes to the sustainability of 
road  improvements.  The  traditional  gender  division  of  labor  can  be  challenged  by  proactively 
ensuring  women’s  involvement  in  road  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  in  a  culturally  sensitive 
manner.  Areas  identified  by  local  constructors  and  surveyed  communities  for  potential 
involvement  of  women  include  support  services  to  construction  camps  and  bioengineering. 
Women’s effective access to these employment opportunities will require targeted programs of 
labor  skills  transfer.  Timor-Leste  is  characterized  by  low—mostly  underreported—human

two  overriding  development  objectives:  (i)  to  reduce  poverty  in  all  sectors  and  regions  of  the

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

54. 
Traffic  forecasts  by  vehicle  type  and  type  of  traffic  (normal  and  generated)  were 
prepared for the project road sections for 20 years from 2005 to 2024. The forecasts are based 
on expected GDP growth and on the income elasticity for national transport demand in relation 
to GDP growth. According to the International Monetary Fund’s medium-term outlook for Timor-
Leste,  GDP  will  grow  at  5%  per  annum.  Income  elasticity  of  demand  for  normal  traffic  is 
estimated at 1.2. Therefore, growth for normal traffic is estimated at 6%. This applies to all types 
of  vehicles  and  is  justified,  given  the  lack  of  secondary  data  and  any  previous  studies. 
Generated traffic is assumed to represent 10% of normal traffic, adjusted for seasonal patterns. 

 

 14 

A conservative assumption is that no traffic will be generated on roads that are not in very poor 
overall condition. The traffic forecast for the project road sections is summarized in Appendix 8. 

55. 
The  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  for  the  three  project  roads  by  comparing  the 
with-  and  without-project  scenarios  using  the  highway  design  and  management  model  (para. 
28). The economic analysis covers 20 years (2005–2024), based on a rehabilitation period of 1 
year starting in 2007. All benefits and costs are in constant 2005 prices. The economic prices 
are expressed using the world price numeraire. 

The economic costs of the Project are (i) the capital cost, including labor, equipment and 
56. 
materials,  consulting  services,  and  physical  contingency;  and  (ii)  the  costs  of  maintaining  the 
project  roads.  The  economic  benefits  arise  from  (i)  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs, 
particularly repair costs, due to the improved road conditions; (ii) savings in maintenance costs; 
(iii) time savings for road users; and (iv) benefits to generated traffic. The Project will have other 
benefits,  such  as  improved  food  security  and  access  to  economic  and  social  services,  which 
were not included in the economic internal rate of return (EIRR) calculation.  

Using a 12% discount rate, the net present value is $6.85 million and the EIRR 24.1%. 
57. 
The  vehicle  operating  cost  savings  account  for  the  majority  of  the  benefits  (95%  of  the  total). 
The  results  of  the  sensitivity  analysis  confirm  the  Project’s  economic  viability.  The  switching 
value6  for  increased  rehabilitation  costs  is  determined  to  be  92%,  and  the  switching  value  for 
decreased  benefits  44%.  In  the  worst  case  scenario—a  combination  of  increased  costs  and 
decreased benefits—the net present value would be reduced to $3.42 million, and the EIRR to 
17.7%. Detailed economic analysis is in Appendix 9.

A. 

Road Network 

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 

1. 
Roads, the dominant mode of transport in Timor-Leste, carry about 70% of freight and 
90%  of  passenger  traffic.  The  road  network  is  dense  compared  with  other  countries  with 
comparable income levels. The total length of the road network is estimated at 6,040 kilometers 
(km),  consisting  of  1430  km  of  national  roads  linking  district  centers,  870  km  of  district  roads, 
providing links to large administrative centers, and 720 km in Dili and several smaller regional 
towns. The remaining 3,020 km comprises rural access or feeder roads. Urban roads represent 
about  800  km  and  feeder/rural  roads  roughly  3,020  km.  About  1,800  km  of  roads  are  paved, 
representing  a  relatively  large  part  of  the  core  network  (84%).  Almost  100%  of  the  national 
roads are paved, and all were paved at some time. 

The road network is strongly influenced by its spatial and physical environment. A main 
2. 
arterial  road  runs  along  the  semiarid  northern  coast,  serving  the  economic  activity  around  Dili 
and trade connections by sea and  to the west. Connections with the southern economic zone 
cross a mountainous and midland area, which includes steep lands of unstable rock and poor 
soils  that  are  highly  susceptible  to  erosion  and  landslides.  Most  of  the  north–south  road 
connections  are  impassable  year-round  at  this  time.  The  southern  coastal  zone,  which  has 
higher population density, agricultural production, and energy reserves, has a moisture climate 
and  comprises  alluvial  formations  and  numerous  rivers  which  are  prone  to  changing  course 
during the monsoon. The network is thus vulnerable to natural hazards of erosion and flooding, 
and access is frequently cut at high-risk locations during the wet season and frequently remains 
impassable  during  the  dry  season.  The  terrain  and  low  standard  of  roads  limit  the  support 
provided to the economy in the south and midlands, such as coffee and agriculture, and soon 
energy resources. 

3. 
The extensive road network was constructed with relatively low standards of design and 
materials. A pragmatic approach adapting to the often severe terrain conditions were obviously 
used,  resulting  in  a  very  low  horizontal  and  vertical  geometrical  standard  in  mountainous 
regions.  The  road  widths  appear  to  have  been  compromised  according  to  the  actual  terrain 
conditions,  resulting  in  many  very  narrow  roads.  While  100%  of  national  roads  and  71%  of 
district  roads  were  bitumen  paved,  shoulders  are  often  constructed  out  of  impervious  earthen 
material.  This,  combined  with  the  difficult  geological  conditions,  torrential  rains,  and  lack  of 
maintenance,  has  caused  rapid  deterioration  of  the  road  system.  Only  24%  of  national  roads 
and 11% of district roads are currently in good condition. 

B. 

Traffic Volume 

4. 
Traffic volume is small and concentrated around Dili. Traffic counts in 2000 showed that 
one  third  of  the  road  network  outside  urban  centers  carried  more  than  200  vehicles  per  day 
(with  15%  carrying  more  than  500  vehicles  per  day,  less  than  2%  carrying  more  than  1,000 
vehicles per day). One third of the network carried less than 50 vehicles per day. Traffic counts 
conducted in 2005 suggest that the average daily traffic for motorized vehicles is about 160 on 
national  roads,  90  on  district  roads,  30  on  rural  roads,  and  170  on  urban  roads.  The  heaviest 
traffic flows, in excess of 400 vehicles per day, are on the northern coastal road. 

The  truck  fleet  consists  almost  entirely  of  light  and  medium-sized  trucks,  due  to  the 
5. 
narrow  winding  mountainous  roads,  which  are  hardly  passable  for  large  trucks.  The  traffic 
loading  on  the  roads  is  generally  very  light,  and  is  not  the  cause  of  the  poor  condition  of  the 
road network. This is evidenced by the fairly good shape of the payment structure in spite of a 
damaged and washed-out surface due to adverse weather conditions and lack of maintenance 
for more than a decade. In addition, the roads have little rutting—normally a sign of overloading.

C. 

Transport Services 

6. 
Walking  is  the  most  common  mode  of  transportation,  followed  by  small  trucks  and 
microbuses. Transport services are mainly provided by small-scale private companies, with one 
or  two  vehicles,  and  a  small  number  of  vehicle  owner-operators.  The  Government  has  set 
minimum  taxi  fare  rates,  but  has  not  set  rates  for  passenger  and  freight  buses  and  trucks. 
Drivers  associations  are  apparently  developing  and  setting  rates.  Passenger  fares  range  from 
$0.50 to $3.00, depending on the distance, and average approximately $1.00 per one-way trip. 
This is high and not affordable for many rural people, particularly, the poor. On the other hand, 
the  fares  barely  allow  vehicle  operators  to  achieve  a  decent  living  standard.  Half  of  vehicle 
operators  and  owner-operators  are  estimated  to  be  living  below  the  national  poverty  line. 
Operating costs are high, with repair costs averaging about $1,500 per year. Nearly 50% of the 
total repair costs are caused by the poor road conditions. 

D. 

Road Safety 

7. 
Road  fatalities  are  relatively  high  with  more  than  20  persons  per  10,000  vehicles.  A 
recent study of available data gathered at the National Dili Hospital shows that the total number 
of patients from road traffic accidents reached 2,728 or an average of 114 patients per month in 
2002 and 2003. There were 41 deaths for the same period or an average of 2 deaths per month 
associated with road traffic accidents. In 2003, 1,354 road traffic accident patients were treated 
at the emergency facility, accounting for 11% of all hospitalized patients in the same year. The 
potential for even greater accident rates is high, considering the increased number of vehicles, 
growing  population,  and  increased  vehicle  speeds  resulting  from  improvements  to  the  road 
network. A national road safety strategy was prepared, but implementation has not started. 

E. 

Institutional Framework 

8. 
The  Government  has  made  great  progress  in  establishing  the  institutions  necessary  to 
run  the  country.  In  the  road  sector,  the  Government  has  established  much  of  the  essential 
framework, including laws, institutions, and development plans. 

9. 
In 2003, the Government introduced two laws to regulate and manage the road sector: 
(i) Basic Law for Vehicle Transport; and (ii) Road Code. The former covers rules and regulations 
governing  vehicle  registration,  road  charges,  passenger  and  freight  transport  services  and 
passenger  fares,  and  planning  and  coordination  of  public  infrastructure  provision.  The  Road 
Code  covers  road  rules,  traffic  management,  classification  and  use  of  roads,  vehicle 
categorization, fines, vehicle emissions, accident reporting, and licensing of drivers.  

The Directorate of Roads, Bridges, and Flood Control (DRBFC) of MPW is responsible 
10. 
for  the  provision  and  management  of  road  infrastructure.  It  operates  through  a  central 
administration  and  five  regional  offices  (in,  Baucau,  Dili,  Maliana,  Oecussi  and  Same).  The 
Directorate  of  Equipment  and  Materials  manages  equipment  owned  by  the  Government. 
DRBFC  has  12  staff  with  engineering  qualifications,  out  of  a  total  of  91.  Due  to  historic 
circumstances,  DRBFC  has  a  very  limited  capacity  for  strategic  planning,  project  preparation 
and  implementation,  construction  supervision,  contract  management,  and  socioeconomic 
evaluation.  

F. 

Government Vision and Strategy  

11. 
The  Government  currently  is  faced  with  managing  a  degraded  road  network,  which

Description of the Environment 

1. 

Physical Resources 

5. 
Timor-Leste comprised the eastern end of the island of Timor, plus the enclave territory 
of  Oecusi  and  the  islands  of  Atauro  and  Jaco;  this  amounts  to  a  land  area  of  about  14,609 
square  kilometers.  Timor  is  the  easternmost  of  the  Lesser  Sunda  islands,  lying  from  8–10 
degrees south of the equator and about 500 km north of Australia.2 The country has a dramatic 
and  mountainous  topography,  dominated  by  the  Ramelau  Mountains  stretching  across  the 
middle of the island from the eastern to the western tip.  

6. 
The island is unique among the major islands of the Sunda archipelago in that it is not of 
volcanic  origin,  but  is  a  continental  fragment,  composed  largely  of  limestone  and  other 
sedimentary  deposits.  The  island  is  geologically  young,  with  steep  and  unstable  slopes  and 
deep valleys, prone to flash floods. More than 40% of the land area is estimated to have a slope 
of greater than 40%3. The steep topography and torrential rains result in thin and unstable soils, 
with  low  water-holding  capacity  (footnote  2).  Occasionally  deeper  soils  may  be  found  on  the 
coastal and inland plains.  

7. 
The  climate  is  hot  and  humid  tropical,  with  large  variations  in  rainfall  and  temperature 
over  short  distances  due  to  the  steep  topography.  Broadly  speaking  two  annual  seasons  are 
determined  by  the  monsoon,  which  varies  in  length  according  to  location.  Timor-Leste  is 
significantly drier than the other islands in the archipelago. The Ramelau Mountain ridge forms 
the main watershed in the country and is the source of all major streams. Even with more than 
100 rivers, surface water is scarce, as most rivers are not perennial. The country has only one 
lake of significant size (Iralalaru lake in the east). Most water for domestic and agricultural use is 
obtained from streams and springs, with the exception of the eastern part of the country, where 
wells are fairly common.  

8. 
Baseline  data  for  air  or  water  quality  is  lacking.  Given  that  the  country  is  very 
underdeveloped with almost no industrial infrastructure and very little vehicular traffic, air quality 
can be expected to be good overall. Despite the generally sparse traffic, vehicular emissions in 
urban  areas  may  sometimes  produce  significant  levels  of  pollution.  The  other  major  source  of 
air pollution is smoke from the burning of wood as a cooking fuel.  

The  country  has  few  water-polluting  industries;  the  processing  of  coffee  beans  is  the

Ecological Resources 

Since  Timor-Leste  is  an  island,  fisheries  and  other  marine  resources  constitute  an 
12. 
important  segment  of  the  natural  environment.  Overall,  the  marine  and  coastal  environments 
appear to be more intact here than on most other islands in the region. Overexploitation of the 
resource in general, and overfishing by commercial interests in particular, are not identified as 
problems at this point. Since the Project is not anticipated to impact the marine resources, these 
resources are not discussed in detail here. 

13. 
Timor-Leste is situated east of the Wallace line and, therefore, has biological elements 
of both Asian and Australian origin. This creates the potential for unique species. However, no 
up-to-date information is available on the number or location of remaining native species, with a 
few exceptions regarding bird species. Nearly 200 species of mammals have been identified on 
the island, but their status today is poorly known. Much of the wildlife commonly seen today is 
feral domestics, such as cattle, buffalo, donkeys, and pigs. Native wildlife can only be seen in 
the  more  isolated  forest  areas  (for  example,  deer,  monkeys,  civets,  cuscus,  and  a  variety  of 
bat). Reptiles are very poorly described. Cobras, pythons, and crocodiles are said to inhabit the 
island, but nothing is known of their number or distribution (footnote 3). Both hunting and trading 
in  protected  species  are  prohibited  under  United  Nations  regulations,  but  both  practices  were 
observed during the project surveys. The Project will not affect any protected natural areas or 
ecologically isolated habitats, and no impacts are anticipated on native wildlife.  

Numerous primary and secondary documentary sources describe massive deforestation 
14. 
in  recent  years,  and  this  was  confirmed  by  the  environmental  field  surveys.  Estimates  of 
clearing  range  as  high  as  90%  of  the  original  forest  cover.  Today  the  dominant  vegetation 
across  the  island  and  within  the  project  area  is  savannah/grassland,  interspersed  with  shrubs 
and  occasional  stands  of  trees.  Most  lands  show  evidence  of  clearing  and  significant 
disturbance by  human  activities,  especially  slash-and-burn  cultivation,  and  coffee  growing  and 
grazing,  even  on  steep  slopes.  In  the  one  project  area  where  sizable  stands  of  forest  were 
observed (Road A08 Lospalos), the forest was definitely secondary rather than primary.  

By far the most common ecosystems on the island are the grasslands and what Carter

left  unattended,  regrowth  communities  range  from  simple  herbaceous  communities  to  areas 
with scattered bamboo, casuarinas, and eucalypts, and structurally more complex communities 
that include dense formations of shrubs, small trees, and creepers” (footnote 3). Field surveys

Economic Development 

18. 
The  population  of  Timor-Leste  ranges  from  750,000  to  1,000,000  and  is  young,  with  a 
median  age  of  20  years.  Life  expectancy  at  birth  is  57  years,  well  below  the  average  for  east 
Asian  and  Pacific  island  countries.  The  population  is  predominately  rural  (75%).  Timor-Leste 
has  one  of  the  least-developed  economies  in  the  region.  The  UNDP  Human  Development 
Index4  places  Timor-Leste  in  the  low  human  development  category,  ranking  158  among  177 
countries.  

19. 
In late 1999, about 70% of the economic infrastructure of Timor-Leste was laid to waste 
by  Indonesian  troops  and  anti-independence  militias;  260,000  people  fled  westward.  Over  the 
next 3 years, a massive international program, staffed by 5,000 peacekeepers (8,000 at peak) 
and 1,300 police officers, led to substantial reconstruction in both urban and rural areas. By mid-
2002,  all  but  about  50,000  of  the  refugees  had  returned.  Growth,  however,  was  held  back  in 
2003 by extensive drought and the gradual winding down of the international presence. 

20. 
As yet, no infrastructure supports tourism and virtually no industry exists. The agriculture 
sector is weak due to recently deficient monsoons, an inequitable land tenure system, and lack 
of education and training for farmers. Since roads provide the dominant form of transportation, 
the  lack  of  a  serviceable  road  infrastructure  contributes  significantly  to  the  prevalence  of 
poverty.

outweigh  the  adverse  impacts,  provided  that  best  engineering  practices  are  followed  and  the 
EMP is effectively implemented. Impacts on environmental, cultural, and human resources are 
identified in the respective sections of this SIEE. Those impacts are summarized here.  

27. 
Erosion  of  soil  and  sedimentation  of  waterways  are  two  of  the  most  pervasive  impacts 
from  road  rehabilitation  projects.  Sediment  deposition  and  suspension  in  water  courses  have 
direct, negative impacts on water quality and aquatic ecosystems. Soil loss and redeposit can 
also adversely affect residential and agricultural properties. A related set of impacts are loss of 
native vegetation and the opening of habitats to the invasion of weeds. These impacts can be 
substantially  mitigated  or  avoided  altogether  by  implementing  engineering  best  practices  and 
bioengineering.  Restricting  earth-moving  and  clearing  activities  to  the  dry  season  will  likewise 
greatly reduce the potential adverse impacts of road rehabilitation. 

The  potential  reduction  in  water  quality  is  a  concern.  Prevention  of  erosion  and  proper 
28. 
handling of sediment will largely prevent any reduction in water quality due to added sediment 
load. Proper storage, handling, and disposal of potential contaminants (such as fuels, lubricants, 
and  solvents)  will  generally  provide  adequate  protection  of  water  quality  from  these  potential 
sources  of  contamination.  The  waste  and  runoff  from  encampments  must  also  be  handled  in 
accordance with the EMP to prevent adverse impacts on water quality. 

29. 
Quarrying  and  extraction  of  construction  materials  must  be  strictly  regulated  in 
accordance  with  Government  guidelines  and  the  EMP,  to  avoid  such  adverse  impacts  as 
reduced  water  quality,  destruction  of  aesthetic  values,  and  creation  of  a  long-term  safety 
hazard.  

30. 
The  siting  of  encampments  will  be  a  critical  issue.  Encampments  must  be  situated  so 
that  they  do  not  seriously  degrade  the  natural  or  social  environment.  Waste  and  effluent  from 
encampments must be contained and disposed of safely, away from water courses, wells, and 
dwellings. 

Disruption  and  delay  of  traffic  plus  the  generation  of  noise,  vibration,  and  dust  are 
31. 
impacts  that  will  be  particularly  noticeable  to  the  local  population.  Asphalt  mixing  plants  may 
produce a significant amount of air pollution. These impacts cannot be entirely avoided, as they 
are part of the nature of a construction project. However, they are temporary and can be greatly 
mitigated  through  proper  planning  and  scheduling,  proper  maintenance  of  equipment,  and 
following the EMP.  

32. 
The majority of potentially adverse impacts are temporary and will cease with the end of 
project  construction.  Provided  that  proper  maintenance  is  given  to  the  roads  throughout  their 
operational life, no significant adverse impacts will result from the existence and operation of the 
roads themselves. Maintenance activities will produce minor impacts, but these are manageable

through  a  continuation  of  the  engineering  practices  and  mitigation  measures  specified  by  the 
EMP.  

33. 
The  anticipated  beneficial  effects  of  the  Project  will  be  long  term  and  will  continue 
throughout the life of the project roads. The installation of proper drainage structures, coupled 
with the planned bioengineering features (such as planting of native species and erosion control 
measures), will greatly reduce the risk of landslides on the roads, thus improving traffic safety. 
These  features  will  also  help  protect  habitations  and  agricultural  lands  from  excessive  runoff 
and sedimentation. Water quality will be protected and will  be improved relative to the current 
condition.  Driving  times  and  costs  will  be  reduced,  while  access  to  markets  and  essential 
services will be greatly improved.

2. 

Environmental Monitoring Plan 

36. 
The  provisions  of  the  EMP  are  designed  to  avoid  adverse  environmental  impacts 
wherever  possible  and  to  mitigate  adverse  effects  to  an  acceptable  level  where  complete 
avoidance is not feasible. Enforcement of the EMP will be the responsibility of the international 
environmental inspector, acting on behalf of the PMU. The international inspector will work with 
the  respective  contractors’  environmental  specialists  and  will  have  direct  access  to  the  PMU 
manager to resolve problems.  

37. 
The  EMP  requires  routine  monitoring  of  air  and  water  quality,  noise  levels,  and  waste 
management  throughout  the  construction  phase  of  the  Project.  Sampling  locations  and 
frequencies are designed to ensure that no significant degradations of quality of life indicators 
occur,  especially  near  population  centers.  Proper  selection  and  prior  approval  will  be  required 
for  the  location  of  staging  areas,  encampments,  and  building  materials  extraction  sites.  Earth-
moving  activities  will  be  restricted  to  the  dry  season  to  minimize  siltation.  The  movement  of 
construction-related vehicles will be routinely monitored to minimize disturbance to vegetation, 
and cleared areas will be reseeded promptly.

G. 

Findings, Recommendations, and Conclusion 

43. 
The three project roads were surveyed by a team of environmental specialists. There is 
no  undisturbed  habitat  in  the  project  impact  area.  Road  A08  between  Iliomar  and  Lospalos 
passes through secondary forest. Within the forest, no general tree cutting will occur; selected 
trees  will  be  removed  only  where  absolutely  necessary  to  maintain  safety  standards  for  the 
road.  Provided  the  requirements  of  the  EMP  are  met,  to  mitigate  potentially  adverse  impacts 
during  project  construction,  no  significant  or  long-term  impacts  will  be  made  on  the  forested 
area,  and  no  additional  or  special  studies  are  needed.  A  replanting  program  will  replace  cut 
trees. The Project will not affect any PNAs or registered cultural/historical sites.  

44. 
Overall,  the  project  area  has  been  subjected  to  long-term,  intense  agricultural  and 
grazing  activities.  The  lands  in  the  vicinity  of  the  project  roads  have  been  heavily  disturbed. 
Slash-and-burn  agricultural  techniques  and  the  grazing  of  domesticated  animals  are  common 
throughout the project area. Many areas are nearly devoid of vegetation cover from overgrazing. 
This environment is dominated by introduced or weedy species of plants and by domesticated 
species of animals, and is generally not able to support native fauna species. No known species 
of endangered plants or animals are found in the project area. 

45. 
Residential areas are found along all three project roads. No habitations are within the 
existing right-of-way, and no involuntary relocation of residents is required. Short-term adverse 
impacts on habitations during project construction are primarily noise, vibration, and increased 
dust.  Careful  adherence  to  the  specifications  of  the  EMP  will  adequately  mitigate  these

construction-related  impacts.  The  Project  will  have  no  long-term  adverse  impacts  on  the  local 
society  and  no  negative  implications  for  vulnerable  groups.  No  minority  ethnic  groups  or 
indigenous population groups live in the project area.   

46. 
The  construction  of  improved  drainage  structures,  stabilization  of  slopes,  replanting  of 
the right-of-way with a proper mix of native species, and other similar measures undertaken by 
the  Project  will  have  long-term  beneficial  effects  on  the  environment.  The  frequency  and 
severity of landslides will be reduced along the project roads. The replanting of trees and native 
vegetation will stabilize the landscape, may help improve water quality, and will enhance scenic 
beauty. The greatly improved ability of the population to move from place to place and to access 
much-needed  social  services  will  be  a  substantial  and  long-term  enhancement.  The  overall, 
long-term effect of the Project on society will be to generate employment and improve access to 
markets  and  social  services.  The  potential  for  economic  growth  and  income-generating 
opportunities,  expected  impact  on  poverty  reduction,  and  enhanced  overall  connectivity  of  the 
core road network will promote sustainable economic and social growth.  

47. 
The  findings  of  the  IEE  confirm  that  this  Project  be  designated  as  ADB  environmental 
category  B.  Therefore,  no  additional  environmental  investigations  are  required.  The  report 
recommends that (i) the Project proceed as proposed in the accompanying reports and that the 
requirements  of  the  EMP  be  incorporated  into  all  subsequent  project  activities  and  contract 
bidding  documents,  and  (ii)  the  construction  supervision  contractor  be  required  to  retain  the 
services of a qualified international environmental inspector. The environmental inspector must 
report  directly  to  the  construction  supervision  contractor  and  will  serve  as  the  single  point  of 
contact  between  the  Ministry  of  Development  and  Environment,  the  construction  supervision 
contractor, and the individual construction contractors.
